questions.text: Koeppe's nodule body is seen on:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Iris Ref: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th ed. pg. 427 • Koeppe nodules are inflammatory cell precipitates and could be found in non-granulomatous as well as granulomatous uveitis • Koeppe nodules are located on the pupillary margin of iris and may be the site of posterior synechiae formation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented to the Ophthalmology Clinic with foamy lesion in eyes as shown in the image below. Which vitamin deficiency can be suspected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vitamin A Ref: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th ed. pg.247 • Bitot's spots are typically dry-appearing triangular patches of xerosed conjunctiva with a layer of foam on the surface, usually located temporal to the cornea. • They mainly composed of keratin admixture with gas-forming bacteria Corynebacterium xerosis, lead to foamy appearance. • Bitot's spots are characteristic of Vitamin A deficiency and are not caused by any other condition.

choices.text: Increase the length/size of lens capsule with the growth/ age

questions.text: A child is supposed to undergo cataract surgery. Based on the guidelines, the under corrected IOL power is calculated by anticipating the expected
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myopic shift Ref: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th ed. pg. 319 • The major postoperative refractive error at the follow-up is myopia. Thus, it is important to adjust the IOL calculation formula to specify more undercorrection, with the aim of achieving more optimal refractive outcomes in adulthood. • Based on guidelines, the under corrected IOL power was calculated by anticipating the expected myopic shift. Under correction: • By 20% if the age is less than 2 years • By 10% if the age is less than 8 years • Full correction after 8 years, because of emmetropia FIGURE: Tear drop sign on CT scan is characteristic finding of orbital floor fracture

questions.text: 13-year-old boy presented to Ophthalmology clinic with a large, rapidly growing cauliflower-like mass protruding out of the left orbit and invading the surrounding soft issues. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Retinoblastoma Ref: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th ed. pg. 860 • Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood • Leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) is the commonest presentation • Tumors are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts) with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm • Well-differentiated tumour shows abundant Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes

questions.text: 12 years old boy suffered orbit injury with a cricket ball. Next day develop diplopia with up gaze. The boy develops headache, dizziness, vomiting on looking up. Also develops bradycardia and hypotension on looking up. No congestion or proptosis of eye. Probable cause:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fracture floor of orbit Ref: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th ed. pg. 894 • A blow-out fracture of the orbital floor is typically caused by a sudden increase in the orbital pressure from an impacting object that is greater in diameter than the orbital aperture. • The common mechanisms are falls, high-velocity ball-related sports, traffic accidents, and interpersonal violence. • The trauma mechanism is a blunt, directed force that may be aimed at the eye without a pressure component toward the eye rim, leading to an increase of pressure inside the orbit with a fracture of the bony structures.

questions.text: The girl patient was myopic having problem in reading and she was using her sisters contact lens. Sharing of contact lens from 1 person to another person can lead to infection by which of the following organism.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acanthamoeba • Acanthamoeba keratitis is a serious corneal infection that can lead to visual loss or a need for corneal transplant. • Acanthamoeba keratitis is most frequently associated with contact lens wear, especially if tap water is used for rinsing. • Symptoms of an infection include redness, pain, tearing, increased light sensitivity, blurry vision, foreign body sensation, discharge or swelling.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of blindness in children?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vitamin A deficiency • In developing countries like India vit A deficiency is the most common cause of blindness in children. • MCC of vision loss in adults: Cataract

questions.text: On looking through a pin hole the visual acuity of a patient improves. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Refractive error • Pin hole helps in confirming whether the optical correction in trial frame is correct or not. • An improvement in visual acuity while looking through a pin hole indicates that optical correction in the trial frame is incorrect, and the possible cause of low vision is refractive error.

questions.text: A patient presents with congestion, itching, foreign body sensation in eye. He has a history of contact lens usage. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Giant papillary conjunctivitis • Giant papillary conjunctivitis also known as mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface like contact lens, prosthesis, exposed nylon sutures and scleral buckle. • It mostly presents with foreign body sensation, itching and congestion. There is associated multiple small papillae development inside of the eyelid.

questions.text: A 67-year-old hypertensive patient presents with acute painless loss of vision. On examination his Visual Acuity is hand movement and he has relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundus image is as shown in the image below. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Branched Retinal Vein Occlusion • Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion is a blockage of branches (one or more) of the central retinal vein, which runs through the optic nerve. • Most common site of BRO is arterio-venous crossings and most common sector involved is superotemporal • 'Wedge shaped distribution of hemorrhage is seen on fundoscopy.

questions.text: Biconcave lenses are used in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myopia

questions.text: A factory worker has trauma to anterior part of eye with iron foreign body. Which of the following investigations would you do for further evaluation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CT scan • CT scan is the investigation of choice for metallic FB. • MRI is contraindicated for metallic FB. • There is no significance of nuclear imaging here • USG B scan is mainly done for the posterior segment of eyeball.

questions.text: A patient presents with blunt trauma to anterior part of lens. What type of cataract may develop in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rosette cataract • Rossette Shaped Cataract is a posterior subcapsular developed due to minute ruptures in lens capsule with influx of aqueous leading to pacification. • It is caused due to blunt trauma

questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old child presents with a picture like the following with intraocular calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Retinoblastoma • Leucocoria or yellowish white pupillary reflex is seen in the shown image. This also known as amaurotic cat's eye appearance. • It is seen in retinoblastoma, a most common intraocular tumor among pediatric population

questions.text: A farmer presented with pain photophobia and watering from eye since last 36 hours. On examination 1 × 2 cm ulcer is seen as shown in image. Identify the lesion shown:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Satellite lesions • The given condition is of fungal keratitis. It is mostly seen among farmers. • MC organism: Fusarium, Aspergillus • Patient present with photophobia, discharge, redness, blurred vision, excessive tearing • Upon examination: satellite lesion is seen. • HPE: organism is seen as Filamentary fungi, the corneal lesions have a whitish gray infiltrate with feathery border

questions.text: A child presents with defective vision which does not improve with glasses, but fundus is normal. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Amblyopia Amblyopia implies a partial loss of sight in one or both the eyes, in the absence of ophthalmoscopic or other marked objective signs.

questions.text: Identify the condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Entropion • The shown image is of entropion. • Entropion refers to inward rolling and rotation of the lid margin toward globe. • Ectropion: Outward rotation of lower eyelid.

questions.text: A patient presents with paralysis of all extraocular muscles. The most probable site of lesion is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Midbrain In first line of explanation, the extraocular muscles are supplied by 3,4 ,6 cranial nerve ... Rest everything is correct

questions.text: After a fight, patient presents with painful ocular movements and a non-reacting pupil. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Optic neuritis The given clinical feature suggests traumatic optic neuropathy. Traumatic optic neuropathy is of two types - direct and indirect. Characteristic features include: Loss of vision Dilatation of pupil Loss of direct light reflex on affected side RAPD

questions.text: A patient presents with a difference in visual acuity between the two eyes. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anisometropia • Anisometropia is the difference in vision between the two eyes and it interferes with normal binocular vision.

questions.text: In which surgery is the following instrument used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dacryocystorhinostomy • The shown instrument is used for dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR). • In DCR, nan anastomosis is created between the sac and the nasal mucosa to bypass an obstruction in the nasolacrimal duct. • Dacryocystorhinostomy operation can be done by following techniques: • Conventional external approach • Endonasal surgical DCR • Endonasal laser DCR • Endocanalicular DCR

questions.text: Parents of a child complain that he squeezes the eye while watching TV. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Myopia • Myopia or shortsightedness is a type of refractive error in which parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused in front of the retina where accommodation is at rest. • A myopic child often presents with symptoms like: • Moving closer to TV • Squeezing eye while watching TV • Decreased performance at school • Headache or tired looking eyes • Blurred vision

questions.text: A young boy presents with itching, irritation and photophobia every year with onset of hot weather. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis • VKC is recurrent, bilateral, chronic with exacerbations and characteristic white ROPY discharge with intense itching usually in the spring season of summer. This condition is often termed as spring catarrh.

questions.text: A newborn child presents with watering and on examination, the following image is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Buphthalmos At present, the term "buphthalmos" is used to describe the visible enlargement of the eyeball detected at birth or soon after, due to any uncontrolled glaucoma in early childhood. Clinical features of Buphthalmos: • Tearing • Sensitivity to light • Eye irritation • Haziness in the eye

questions.text: A young boy complains of itching, watering of eyes and rhinorrhea. On examination, the following image is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis • The given image is of palpebral form of VKC. • Upon examination: Cobblestone or 'Pavement Stone' appearance with conjunctival hyperemia.

questions.text: A lady suffers sudden painful loss of vision with worsening of pain on eye movements. A relative afferent papillary defect is present. On perimetry, there is a central scotoma in the involved eye. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Optic neuritis Optic neuritis has 3 anatomical types: • Papillitis • Neuroretinitis • Retrobulbar neuritis

questions.text: V-Y procedure is used for correction of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ectropion • The V-Y plasty technique is an island pedicle flap procedure, used for management of ectropion. Contracted upper lid Lower lid ectropion

questions.text: A person has vision of 1/60 in his better eye, what is the type of blindness he has?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Social blindness Definitions of blindness: • Total blindness: Ophthalmology, Absolute (No light perception) • Legal blindness: Vision in better eye <1/60 to perception light • Social blindness: WHO, NCBVI (vision in better eye <3/60 to 1/60) • Economic blindness: Severe VI, work (Vision in better eye <6/60 to 3/60 • Moderate visual impairment

questions.text: A child with history of malnutrition was examined and following image of the eye was seen IOP was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterior staphyloma • The shown condition is anterior staphyloma • It is a localized defect in the anterior eye wall with protrusion of uveal tissue due to alterations in scleral thickness and structure.

questions.text: A lady presents with pain, unilateral proptosis, orbital swelling and loss of vision. On examination, the given image is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Orbital cellulitis • Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the fat and muscles around the eye. Causes: • Streptococcus species • Staphylococcus species • Extension of infection from neighboring structures

questions.text: What is the most common treatment for recurrent pterygium?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) -In explanation, correct answer is C) Conjunctival Autograft. -Add in the explanation: Mitomycin C drops applied pre-operatively /intra-operatively or post operatively to prevent recurrence . However it may lead to complications like scleral necrosis, cataract and iritis , so should be used judiciously. - Conjunctival autografting has less recurrence rates and is a simple and quick procedure which reduces the risk of granuloma formation, scleral thinning and necrosis.

questions.text: A child aged 10 years is having amblyopia in one eye. What is the best treatment in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amblyopia, often referred to as "lazy eye," is a condition where one eye has poor vision that is not corrected by glasses or contact lenses, and it is typically the result of poor visual development during childhood. The condition often affects only one eye. The best treatment for amblyopia in a 10-year-old child is occlusion therapy: Occlusion involves patching the stronger eye (the one with normal vision) to force the weaker eye to work harder, stimulating visual development in that eye. This therapy is the most common and effective method for treating amblyopia, especially in children under 8 to 10 years old. While treatment outcomes are best if started at an earlier age, there is still a possibility of improvement at 10 years old with appropriate intervention. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Observation: Observation alone is not sufficient in treating amblyopia. Without treatment, the weaker eye may not improve, and the child could be left with permanent visual impairment in that eye. C. Penalization: Penalization involves the use of atropine drops in the stronger eye to blur its vision, which encourages the child to use the weaker eye. While penalization can be an alternative to occlusion, occlusion therapy is generally preferred, especially in cases of significant amblyopia. However, penalization might be considered if the child refuses to wear the patch. D. None of the above: Since occlusion is the standard treatment for amblyopia in children, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A man suffered trauma to the right eye with a Which of the following will be the most likely to o this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Inferior orbital wall fracture • Punch/ball injury to eye commonly leads to orbital floor fracture • Blow out fracture usually involves the floor of orbit. Signs include: • Periocular ecchymosis, edema • Infraorbital nerve anesthesia • Double diplopia

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with complicated cataract al slit lamp findings are shown in the given image. What is the type of cataract seen in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Posterior subcapsular cataract • The shown image is of Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC). There is formation of granular or plaque like opacity in the posterior subcapsular cortex. • PSC causes maximum visual disability due to its location at/near the NODAL POINT of the eye. • Clinical feature: • Loss of near vision more than far vision • Vision improves in dim illumination • Glare

questions.text: A person with jaundice and tremors shows following finding in the eye. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Wilson's disease The shown image along with clinical findings are suggestive of sunflower cataract, which is seen in Wilson's disease • Copper deposited starts at limbus in ring form over Descemet membrane of cornea, often termed as KF ring.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male present with history of severe breathlessness, pyrexia, tachypnea, and general, malaise. RT-PCR from a nasopharyngeal swab was positive for the SARS -CoV-2 virus. On day 10, patient developed bilateral orbital swelling with proptosis. What could be the most common organism involved?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mucormycosis • Clinical features and positive RT-PCR is suggestive of infection by mucormycosis is a fungal infection caused by zygomycetes. • Symptoms include: fever, headache, shortness of breath etc. • Complications include blindness, organ dysfunction, or death.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Goldmann applanation tonometer • Goldman applanation tonometry is considered as gold standard for measuring IOP.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the given fundus image of a diabetic patient with painless loss of vision?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) CRVO • TOMATO SPLASH/TOMATO KETCHUP APPEARANCE due to severe hemorrhages involving peripheral and posterior pole. • It is seen in CRVO

questions.text: A person with a brain lesion presents with macula sparing homonymous hemianopia. What could be the site of lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Occipital cortex • Homonymous hemianopia is seen if there is lesion at the site of optic tract • Homonymous hemianopia sparing macula is seen if there is lesion in occipital cortex.

questions.text: Refractive error found here is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myopia and astigmatism -Remove the whole explanation and add this: The image shown is of keratoconus which is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone -like steeping of the Corneal associated with irregular stromal thinning , resulting in a cone -like bulge.

questions.text: The above pathology is associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chlamydia trachomatis • The shown image is SAGO GRAIN FOLLICLES in upper palpebral conjunctiva • It is suggestive of trachoma infection which is caused by chlamydia trachomatis.

choices.text: It can be done with the patient being in any position
Can be used in cases of hazy ocular media
The retinal periphery cannot be examined

questions.text: All of the following are true about above procedure; EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Can be used in cases of hazy ocular media • The shown image is of direct ophthalmoscopy. It produces an Erect image (upright) and magnification 15 times. • In hazy ocular media it cannot be used.

questions.text: A patient was tested for ocular motion and presented with shown ocular motion defect. The position of eyeball is shown in the image below where left eye movement was noted when the object was moved to left lower quadrant, but right eye remain static. Identify the nerve involved in following defect.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) innervates most of the extraocular muscles: superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique, along with levator palpebrae superioris (eyelid elevation) and the parasympathetic fibers to the pupil. In the image, the right eye is deviated “down and out”—this is the hallmark of oculomotor nerve palsy, where only the lateral rectus (abducens) and superior oblique (trochlear) muscles are functioning, pulling the eye laterally and slightly downward. This presentation may also include ptosis and pupil dilation, both due to oculomotor nerve involvement. Incorrect Options: B. Trochlear nerve The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) innervates only the superior oblique muscle, which assists in downward and inward movement of the eye. Damage leads to vertical diplopia (double vision when looking down), and patients may tilt their head away from the affected side. Why incorrect: In trochlear nerve palsy, the eye does not rest in the “down and out” position like in the image, and the dysfunction is more subtle. C. Optic nerve The optic nerve (cranial nerve II) transmits visual information from the retina to the brain. Damage to this nerve causes vision loss or blindness, but does not affect eye movement. Why incorrect: The patient shows no signs of vision loss but rather has abnormal eye position and movement, indicating a motor nerve issue. D. Abducent nerve The abducent nerve (cranial nerve VI) supplies the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye. Damage causes the affected eye to be pulled medially (inward) at rest and the inability to look laterally. Why incorrect: In the image, the affected eye is not deviated medially; instead, it is down and out, which is not consistent with abducent nerve palsy.

questions.text: Spot diagnosis of the given image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Bitot's spots • The given image is of Bitot's spot, caused due to deficiency of Vit A. • According to WHO classification of corneal diseases, it is classified under XIB

questions.text: Which test is being demonstrated here?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Schirmer's test Ref. Khurana 7th ed. pg. 407 • Schirmer's test is used to measures total tear secretions. • This test is used in dry eye disease. • It is performed with the help of a 5 x 35 mm strip of Whatman-41 filter paper. Procedure • This paper is folded 5 mm from one end and place it in the lower fornix at the junction of lateral one-third and medial two-thirds. • Then patient is asked to look up and not to blink or close the eyes. • After 5 minutes wetting of the filter paper take place from the bent end then its reading is measured. • Interpretation of Schirmer-I test - • More than 15 mm = Normal value • Value of 5-10 mm = Moderate to mild keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS). • Value less than 5 mm = severe KCS.

questions.text: Not used for color vision testing:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ames test • Ames test is utilized to determine the mutagenic activity of chemicals by observing they can cause mutation in test bacteria or not. • All other test in choices are utilized in color vision testing. • NOTE: FM-100 Hue test is the most sensitive test for color vision testing FIGURE: FM 100 Hue

questions.text: Corneal endothelium is derived from?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neural crest • Corneal epithelium is derived from surface ectoderm, while corneal endothelium is derived from neural crest.

choices.text: In Hypermetropia the red glow moves in opposite direction
In high myopia, the red glow moves in same direction
In emmetropia the red glow moves in opposite direction
Done from 1 meter distance from patient

questions.text: True about retinoscopy:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Done from 1 meter distance from patient • Retinoscopy aka skiascopy or shadow test is done to check the error of refraction by method of neutralization. • Patient is made to sit at a distance of 1 meter from examiner -> a light is thrown into patient's eye -> through a hole in retinoscope mirror, the examiner observes the red reflex in the pupillary area of patient. • Examiner Look for movement of red reflex/orange streak/bar of light. • If NO movement: Myopia = -1 D • If opposite movement: Myopia > - 1 • Same side movement: Myopia < - 1; Emmetropia =0; Hypermetropia: +1

questions.text: A child presents with night blindness, delay adaptation. Which investigation to be done f confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ERG Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by A.K. Khurana 6th ed. pg. 287 • Dark adaptation is ability of the eye to adapt itself to decreasing illumination. The time taken to see in dim illumination is dark adaptation time. • Rods are more sensitive to low light (scotopic vision) while cones are for bright light. • Delayed dark adaptation: Occur due to disease of rods. Ex: Deficiency of vitamin A, retinitis pigmentosa. RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA • Degenerative disease of the rods • MC affects males in childhood and progress slowly • Inherited as: • AR- in 25% cases; intermediate severity • AD- in 25% cases; least severe • X-linked- least common (10%); most severe Clinical feature: • Night blindness • Delayed dark adaptation • Tubular vision • Triad: Arterioles constriction, Bony spicule pigmentation, Waxy pallor of disc • IOC: Electroretinogram (B wave affected before A wave) • Treatment: Vitamin A 15000 IU orally gd, slow down progression.

questions.text: Newborn is hypermetropic by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) +2 to +3 D EYE AT BIRTH • AP diameter is 16.5 mm, adult size is attained by 7 to 8 years (24 mm) • Corneal diameter 10 mm, adult size attained by 2 years. • Lens spherical. • Lacrimal gland underdeveloped, tears not secreted. • Orbit is more divergent. • Visual acuity 6/60. • Myelination of optic nerve has reached lamina cribrosa.

questions.text: Structure with highest refractive index:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lens • Among the given choices, lens has the highest refractive index of about 1.38 to 1.40.

questions.text: Which is True about PHPV?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Associated with microphthalmia • The primary vitreous used information of the eye during fetal development remains in the eye upon birth and is hazy and scarred. • The persistence of primary vitreous even after birth is said to be persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV). • Symptoms are: Leukocoria, strabismus, nystagmus and blurred vision, blindness. • It is seen almost always unilateral (~90% of the cases) • It is associated with: • Small eye (typically occurs in a microphthalmic eye) • Retinal detachment • Vitreous hemorrhage • If diagnosed at an early stage it may be possible to aspirate the lens followed by excision of the retrolentalmembrane and vitrectomy. • Visual prognosis is poor.

questions.text: In which disease is corneal collagen cross-linking used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Keratoconus Ref: Khurana 7th ed. pg. 137 • Keratoconus is a conical cornea • It is progressive (slowly progress) noninflammatory bilateral ectatic condition of cornea in its axial part. • It usually starts at puberty. • Treatment: • Spectacle correction: Improves vision in early cases • Contact lens: Specially designed scleral contact lens (Rose-K) may be useful. • Intacs, the intracorneal ring segments. Useful due to its flattening effect. • Corneal collagen cross linking with riboflavin (CXL or C3R) and UV-A rays: It slows down the progression of disease • Keratoplasty: In advanced cases.

questions.text: What is the risk factor for acanthamoeba keratitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Extended contact lens wearing ACANTHAMOEBA KERATITIS • Acanthamoeba castellanii is a Causative organism. It is a free-living genus of amoeba found in soil, fresh water, well water, sea water, sewage and air. • In human, acanthamoeba causes: • Keratitis • Fulminant meningoencephalitis. • Granulomatous encephalitis • Corneal infection with acanthamoeba occurs from direct corneal contact with any material or water contaminated Risk factors: • Contact lens wearers • Trauma associated with contaminated matter such as vegetable matter, salt water diving. • Occur as opportunistic infection

questions.text: Which part of the eye can be first involved in patients of Covid-19 patients?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Conjunctiva • In any viral infection including Covid-19 conjunctiva is the first part to be involved, causing conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Art's line is seen in which condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Trachoma • Arlts line is a linear scar present in sulcus subtarsalis i.e. it is conjunctival scarring which may be irregular, star-shaped or linear. • This is present in cicatricial phase of trachoma.

questions.text: Corneal transparency is maintained by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Keratan sulphate Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by A.K. Khurana, 7th ed. pg. 100 • Keratan sulphate (KS) is the predominant glycosaminoglycan (GAG) in the cornea of the eye, where it exists in proteoglycan (PG) form. • KS-PGs has a pivotal role in the establishment and maintenance of the array of regularly-spaced and uniformly- thin collagen fibrils which make up the corneal stroma (the thickest part of cornea). • This characteristic arrangement of fibrils allows light to pass through the cornea. • Mutation in the enzyme for the KS-GAG sulphation can lead to macular corneal dystrophy. Other causes of corneal opacity: • Avascularity • Endothelium; which act as mechanical barrier. Na*K* ATPase of endothelium keeps the cornea in dehydrated state. • Failure of this pump can lead to bullous keratopathy

choices.text: Occurs more commonly in warm areas
This structure is attached to cornea

questions.text: What is NOT correct regarding the clinical condition shown in image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) It causes myopia • The shown condition in the image is pterygium. • Pterygium is a growth of the conjunctiva or mucous membrane that covers the cornea. • This benign or noncancerous wedge-shaped growth. • Most common around nasal side • Exact cause of pterygium is not known. One explanation is that too much exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light can lead to these growths. It occurs more often in people who live in warm climates and spend a lot of time outdoors in sunny or windy environments.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to clinic with difficulty in coordination of movements and abdominal pain. On further examination copper deposition in a ring form is seen in cornea. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Wilson's disease • Wilson's disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder of copper metabolism leading to copper accumulation in many tissues, mainly the liver, brain, cornea and kidney. • Copper deposition leads to specific hepatic, neurological, psychiatric and ocular signs and symptoms. • The ocular manifestations of Wilson's disease include Kayser-Fleischer ring (K-F ring) and sunflower cataract. • K-F ring is almost always bilateral, starts superiorly first and then inferiorly, and later becomes circumferential. • It results due to extracellular copper deposition in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea.

questions.text: Phlyctenular conjunctivitis seen due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Allergic 7th ed. p§. 100 • Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a delayed hypersensitivity response to endogenous protein of microbes. • It is probably a type 4 cell mediated immune response-also called as microbial allergic conjunctivitis. • There is nodule formation on the conjunctival and corneal epithelium to endogenous allergens to which they have become sensitized. • It is more common in girls than boys and more common in undernourished children living in overcrowded and unhygienic conditions in the peak age group of 3-15 years. • It shows the following stages: • Stage of nodule formation • Stage of ulceration • Stage of granulation and • Stage of resolution

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition as shown in image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Keratoconus • The image shows V-shaped protrusion of cornea, which is termed as Munson sign. It is a feature of keratoconus. • Other features of keratoconus: • Vogt's striae: Break in Descemet's membrane • Fleischer's ring: Iron deposition at the back of cornea • Upon retinoscopy: Scissoring reflex

questions.text: Fleischer's ring is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Keratoconus • Fleischer ring is seen in keratoconus. • Kayser-Fleischer ring is seen in Wilsons disease.

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Herpes simplex keratitis • The shown image of dendritic ulcer (feature of viral keratitis) is a direct repeat from previous examination. • The detail of viral infection of cornea has been discussed later in cornea section.

questions.text: Keratometer is used to assess:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Curvature of cornea • Keratometer is used to assess curvature of cornea. • Pachymetry is used for measurement of corneal thickness.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in keratitis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Steroids • Using steroids in active inflammation can cause flare-up of bacterial infection and corneal ulcer may develop.

choices.text: Conjunctiva invasion making a flap over cornea

questions.text: True about pterygium:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Conjunctiva invasion making a flap over cornea PTERYGIUM • It is a degenerative and hyperplastic condition of conjunctiva -> elastotic degeneration and proliferation of subconjunctival tissue • Triangular/wing shaped invasion of conjunctiva upon the cornea. It is common in dry heat, sun exposure (UV rays) and abundant dust. • Iron deposition in the corneal epithelium at the advancing head of the pterygium is called Stocker line. • It usually asymptomatic. • MC site: Nasal side • Primary double pterygium: Involvement of both nasal and temporal side • The corneal epithelium, bowman's layer and superficial stroma are destroyed • Treatment: Surgical excision. • The commonest problem after excision is recurrence which is reduced by postoperative use of mitomycin-C/ thiotepa or by doing surgical excision with free conjunctival graft from same/ other eye

questions.text: Cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Enterovirus • Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis: It is also called Apollo conjunctivitis. • It is caused by picornavirus (enterovirus type 70).

questions.text: Klebsiella pneumoniae causes:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Keratitis • Bacteria which cause purulent keratitis after epithelial injury are pseudomonas, Staphylococcus aureus, Pneumococcus, Moraxella, Streptococcus epidermidis, E.coli, Proteus, Klebsiella. • Clinical feature of keratitis: Pain, lacrimation, photo-phobia, red eye, blurred vision.

questions.text: Which is therapeutic indication of keratoplasty?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Keratoconus • Keratoconus is degenerative disease of cornea, where it becomes conical. It is best treated by keratoplasty. • Keratoplasty is corneal grafting or in more simple term, corneal transplantation. There are two types of keratoplasty: • Penetrating keratoplasty (PK) also known as full thickness keratoplasty • Lamellar keratoplasty (LK) also known as partial Thickness keratoplasty. It has highest success rate as compared to PK. • Indication for keratoplasty: • Corneal scar • Non-healing ulcer • Chemical injuries • Keratoconus • Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy

questions.text: Cherry red spot is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Central retinal artery occlusion Ref: Khurana 7th ed. pg. 277, 546 • Cherry-red spot - present in the center of macula in contrast to the surrounding pale retina. • It is seen due to vascular choroid shining through the thin retina in foveal region, in contrast to the surrounding pale retina Causes of Cherry Red Spot • Central retinal artery occlusion • Tay-Sachs disease • Commotio retinae (Berlin's edema)- due to trauma • Niemann- Pick disease • Gaucher's disease • Sandhoff disease

questions.text: Microaneurysms are found in which disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diabetic retinopathy • Microaneurysms are multiple tiny dot-like dilatations along the venous end of capillaries due to focal dilation (out pouching) of capillary wall following loss of pericyte. • It appear as red dots and leak fluid, proteins, lipids and also fluorescein dye on FFA. • Most commonly found in diabetic retinopathy seen in the macular area. • Also found in: • Hypertensive retinopathy • Retinal vein occlusions • Eales disease • Sickle cell disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in acute anterior uveitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Atropine • Acute uveitis: Inflammation of uveal region of the eye, namely iris, choroid and ciliary body. In this sudden symptomatic onset and it lasts for about 6 weeks to 3 months. • Main symptoms of acute anterior uveitis: Pain, photophobia, redness, lacrimation and decreased vision. Treatment • Local therapy: • Cycloplegic drugs: Most effective during acute phase of iridocyclitis. • Dose: 1% atropine sulfate eye ointment or drops instilled 2-3 times a day. • Mechanism of action: • Gives comfort and rest to the eye by relieving spasm of muscles • Prevents the formation of synechiae • Break already formed synechiae • Reduces exudation • By relieving pressure on the anterior ciliary arteries it increases the blood supply to anterior uvea. • Systemic therapy: • Corticosteroid (DOC) • NSAIDs • Immunosuppressive drugs

questions.text: Identify the investigation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fluorescein angiography • The shown investigation is fluorescein angiography

questions.text: Which one of them is seen in iridocyclitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Keratic precipitates • Keratic precipitates (KPs) are the pathognomonic sign of anterior uveitis. • KPs are proteinaceous cellular deposits occurring at the back of cornea, arranged in a triangular fashion present in center and inferior part of cornea due to convection currents in the aqueous humor. • Types of KPs: • Mutton fat KPs-seen in chronic granulomatous diseases (Ex: Sarcoidosis, Leprosy etc) • Small and medium KPs (granular KPs) • Fine KPs, also called as 'stellate KPs • Old KPs. These are sign of healed uveitis.

questions.text: A patient presented in OPD with anterior uveitis. Which of the following can be associated with his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) HLA B27 Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by A.K. Khurana, 7th ed. pg. 174 • Uveitis is many times associated with infectious and noninfectious systemic diseases like sarcoidosis, Behçet's disease, ankylosing spondylitis, Reiter's syndrome, juvenile idiopathic arthritis and Fuchs' heterochromic uveitis. • In ankylosing spondylitis there is uveitis associated with an idiopathic chronic inflammatory arthritis involving the sacral iliac and posterior intervertebral joints. • It mostly involves young people positive for HLA-B27 and the uveitis is mostly acute anterior iridocyclitis. Conditions associated with HLA B27 • Psoriasis • Ankylosing spondylitis • Inflammatory bowel disease • Reiter's syndrome

questions.text: A young patient presented with acute onset severe pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterior uveitis • The irregularly dilated pupil shown in the image is festooned pupil. • It is feature of acute anterior uveitis • Other features of anterior uveitis: Keratic precipitate, Arlt's triangle.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Arteriolar attenuation Fundal changes in retinitis pigmentosa: • Retinal pigmentary changes: Perivascular, jet black spots resembling bony corpuscles in shape • Retinal arterioles are attenuated (narrowed), may become thread like in later stages • Thinning and atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium • Pale, waxy optic disc Clinical features of RP: • Night blindness: Characteristic earliest feature • Delayed dark adaptation • Tubular vision (preserved central vision, lost after many years) RP is inherited as: • AR: Most common (intermediate severity) • AD: Least severe • X-Linked: Least common (Most severe)

questions.text: Sarcoidosis is associated with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anterior uveitis Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by A.K. Khurana 6th ed. pg. 167 UVEITIS IN SARCOIDOSIS • Sarcoidosis is one of the chronic granulomatous disease that can cause non-infective uveitis • MC age group: 20-50 years; F > M • Associated feature: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, pulmonary infiltration, skin and ocular lesions • 20-50% of sarcoidosis patients present with ocular lesions like: • Sarcoid uveitis: Can cause anterior, posterior or intermediate panuveitis • Anterior uveitis: Large mutton fat KP, Bussaca nodule, anterior chamber cells and flare • Intermediate uveitis: Characterized by snow balls and snow banking • Posterior uveitis: Present with cystoid macular edema, periphlebitis retinae with sheathing, appearing as candle wax dripping, peripheral multifocal chorioretinitis characterised by small, punched out atrophic spots (it is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis). • Uveoparotid fever: Aka Heerfordt's syndrome: • Characterized by bilateral granulomatous panuveitis with painful enlargement of parotid gland, rash, fever and cranial nerve palsies. DIAGNOSIS: • Abnormal Chest X-ray (in 90% cases) • Kveim test: +ve • Serum ACE level Treatment: Steroids

questions.text: Cattle track appearance is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Central retinal artery occlusion Ref: Walsh and Hoyt; Vol. 3, pg. 3370 • Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO): Presents with sudden painless loss of vision. Causes are: • Artery occlusion by the Emboli: It is most common cause. • Other causes: Giant cell arteritis, SLE, scleroderma. • Fundus appears milky white because of retinal edema. There is cherry red spot. Due to embolus the blood column within the retina is segmented and is known as cattle tracking. • Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO): Its incidence is more common than CRAO. Causes are: • Hypertension, diabetes mellitus, atherosclerosis. • Upon examination: Tortuous and engorged veins, disc edema, soft exudate and evidence of rubeosis iridis (new vessel on iris) • Central serous retinopathy (CSR): It is due to accumulation of transparent fluid at the posterior pole specially macula causing a circumscribed area of retinal detachment in the macular region. Causes are: • Raised aldosterone level usually among type A personalities • Cushing syndrome, idiopathic. Fluorescein angiography shows ink blot pattern and smoke stack pattern. Diabetic retinopathy: It is of 2 types: • Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR): Findings/changes in NPDR are: • Microaneurysm: Earliest change • Retinal hemorrhage • Hard and soft exudates. • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR): Findings/ changes in PDR are: • Neovascularization: Hallmark • Vitreous hemorrhage, and • Retinal detachment.

questions.text: What is the size of optic disc?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 1.5 mm Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by Khurana 9th ed. pg. 6 • The average optic disc is 1500 microns (or 1.5 millimeters) in size where optic nerve enters into the back of the eye. • Small optic disc is said when vertical diameter of optic disc is 2.2 mm. • Length of optic nerve is 47-50 mm and has 4 parts: • Intraocular: 1 mm • Intraorbital: 30 mm • Intracanalicular: 6-9 mm • Intracranial: 10 mm

questions.text: In uveitis, site of keratic precipitate is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Corneal endothelium Ref; Comprehensive Ophthalmology by Khurana 6th ed.pg. 31 • Keratic precipitate (K) is deposition of protein on the corneal endothelium in patients with anterior uveitis. • This KP is deposited in a triangular fashion, known as Arlt's triangle. • In some chronic granulomatous diseases like sarcoidosis, leprosy, TB, there is deposition of special KP's known as mutton fat KP. • Mechanism of action: • Relieves spasm of iris sphincter and ciliary body, which gives immediate relief and comfort from pain. • Prevents synechiae formation and breaks them as well. • Decreases hyperemia which reduces exudation. • Increases blood supply to anterior uvea by relieving pressure on anterior ciliary artery, which adds to more absorption of toxin.

questions.text: How many years does it take to develop retinopathy in case of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus type?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1-5 • Poor sugar control (glycosylated hemoglobin > 7%) leads to development of diabetic retinopathy within 5 years in type 1 diabetes mellitus and over 15-20 years in type 2 diabetes mellitus. • Diabetics have 25 times higher chances of blindness as compared to nondiabetics. Extra Mile • Most common cause of visual loss in a diabetic is macular edema. • Best method to detect visual loss is FFA or optical coherence tomography. • Most common cause of blindness in diabetic is retinal detachment. • Diabetic retinopathy and nephropathy progress over same duration and always co-exist. • Best predictor for development of retinopathy is duration of diabetes

questions.text: Instrument shown in the image is used for which of the following clinical condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Instrument for chalazion • Chalazion clamp is applied to the everted lower lid. The clamp is tightened and used to evert and expose the conjunctival aspect of the eyelid. • The clamp aid controls bleeding during the procedure and helps in fair localization of the lesion. • Chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like a forceps which can be clamped with the help of a screw. • One of the limbs that are placed on the skin side is in the form of a disc while the one that is placed on the conjunctival side is a circular ring.

questions.text: A 5-year-old suffering with chronic epiphora has appeared in the clinic. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dacryocystorhinostomy • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a surgical procedure to restore the flow of tears into the nose from the lacrimal sac when the nasolacrimal duct does not function. • Reference states: The operation can be performed by following techniques • Conventional external approach • Endonasal surgical DCR • Endonasal laser DCR • Endocanalicular laser DCR • NOTE: Atrophic rhinitis is an absolute contraindication of DCR. • In case of acute dacryocystitis, this operation cannot be done immediately, rather it is done after a period of time. • In case of elderly patients (above 70 years of age), dacryocystectomy is more preferred than dacryocystorhinostomy as old age naturally causes atrophy in nasal mucosa.

questions.text: Appropriate treatment for the congenital ptosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) LPS resection • For congenital ptosis surgery is the treatment of choice. • Ptosis is drooping of eyelids and its severity is graded by (Amount of cornea covered by eyelid - 2) • Mild ptosis: 2 mm • Moderate ptosis: 3 mm • Severe ptosis: 4 mm • In severe cases surgery should be performed as soon as possible in order to avoid amblyopia. • In mild and moderate cases surgery can be delayed until the age of 3 to 4 years. • There are many surgeries for ptosis like • Fasanella Servat Operation for mild ptosis • Blaskovics operation, LPS Resection for moderate-severe ptosis • Frontalis Sling. Surgery for completely paralyzed levator muscle Note: • Tarsal fracture and Wedge resection are the surgeries for entropion.

questions.text: Internal hordeolum is due to inflammation of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Meibomian glands GLANDS OF EYE AND ITS ASSOCIATED PATHOLOGY

questions.text: Chronic granulomatous inflammation in upper lid with painless swelling is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Chalazion • Chalazion is Chronic granulomatous painless inflammation of Meibomian Gland. • Treatment: Incision and drainage

questions.text: In Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), lacrimal gland opens into:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Middle meatus • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is a surgical procedure of choice in patients with dacryocystitis (inflammation of lacrimal sac) • It is done by creating a new drainage of tear into nose, which opens in middle meatus. • Remember: Normally nasolacrimal duct opens into inferior meatus. • The medial wall of lacrimal sac is anastomosed with middle meatus of nose -> overcoming the obstruction at the junction of lacrimal sac and nasolacrimal duct. • Performed in patients below 60 years. Extra Mile • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): used only when DCR is contraindicated or when the patient is too young (60 ears) or in cases of chronic granulomatous disease induced obstruction like syphilis, TB, leprosy. • Coniunctivodacryocystorhinostomy (CDCR): Done in presence of blocked canaliculi

questions.text: Shallow anterior chamber is seen in which of the following condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hypermetropia • Anterior chamber is the space between posterior surface of cornea to anterior surface of lens. • Normal depth: 2.5 mm and contains 0.25 ml of aqueous humor • NOTE: Chamber depth decreases by 0.01 mm/year of life • Anterior chamber is shallow in: • Physiological: Young age and in Elderly persons • Diseases: ACG, Hypermetropia, perforated cornea, iris bombe, adherent leucoma can cause shallow anterior chamber • Anterior chamber is deep in: • Aphakia, Myopia, Keratoconus, Keratoglobus, Buphthalmos, total posterior synechiae can cause deep anterior chamber.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common ocular pre entation of Marfan's syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Subluxation of lens • Marfans syndrome is an autosomal dominant mesodermal dysplasia. • In this lens is displaced upwards and temporally bilaterally symmetrical.

questions.text: Which laser is used in laser assisted cataract surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Femto laser • Femto second laser assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) - It is the best available procedure presently for doing cataract surgery. • FLACS is basically a microincision cataract surgery (MICS) in which femtosecond laser (FSL) is used. Note: • Laser iridotomy for ACG (uses ND:YAG laser) Argon laser trabeculoplasty for OAG

questions.text: A patient comes to OPD with decreased vision in h left eye and pacification of cornea as shown in image On history he said that he had undergone cataract surgery 6 years back. What is the next line of management in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Keratoplasty • Corneal transplantation, also known as corneal grafting, is a surgical procedure where a damaged or diseased cornea is replaced by donated corneal tissue (the graft). • Keratoplasty simply means surgery to the cornea. The graft is taken from a recently deceased individual with no known diseases or other factors that may affect the chance of survival of the donated tissue or the health of the recipient. • Types of keratoplasty: • Penetrating keratoplasty: Entire cornea is replaced • Lamellar keratoplasty: Only part of the cornea is replaced

questions.text: Advantage of contact lens over normal glasses:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prismatic effect will less Contact lens have the following advantages over spectacles: • Irregular corneal astigmatism can be corrected • They provide normal field of vision • Prismatic distortions can be corrected • Binocular vision can be retained in high anisometropia • Cosmetically better

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness in India:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cataract • Globally, MCC of blindness is cataract, affecting 17.6 million (39%), followed by glaucoma which affects 4.5 million (10%) population. • MCC of blindness in India: Cataract • MCC of blindness in developed countries: Age Related Macular Degeneration (50% of all blindness in developed countries) • MCC of blindness in developing countries: Cataract • MC preventable cause of blindness worldwide: Trachoma

questions.text: For Laser iridotomy which laser is used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ND:YAG laser • Lasers for glaucoma: • Laser iridotomy for ACG (uses ND:YAG laser) • Argon laser trabeculoplasty for OAG • Laser goniopunctures for developmental glaucoma • Pan retinal photocoagulation: For prophylactic/ treatment of neovascular glaucoma • Cyclophotocoagulation: For absolute glaucoma or near absolute glaucoma • Nd:YAG laser typically emits light with wavelength of 1064 nm in the infrared • Uses of Nd:YAG laser: • Correct posterior capsular pacification • Peripheral laser iridotomy in ACG • Double frequency ND:YAG (wavelength: 532 nm) used for pan-retinal photocoagulation. Extra Mile • Excimer lasers are used for photoablation -these lasers act by tissue remodeling. Used for: • Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) • LASIK surgery • Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) for corneal diseases such as band shaped keratopathy.

questions.text: Ectopia lentis is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Homocystinuria Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by A.K. Khurana 6th ed. P 216 Systemic conditions associated with ectopia lentis: • Marfan syndrome: MCC of hereditary ectopia lentis. AD condition. Lens displaced supero-temporally (bilaterally symmetrical) • Homocystinuria: 2nd MCC of hereditary ectopia lentis. AR condition. Lens subluxated inferior and nasally. • Weil Marchesani syndrome: AR condition. Associated with mental retardation, short stature and stubby fingers. Lens subluxated anteriorly. • Sulphite oxidase deficiency: AR condition. Ectopia lentis is universal ocular feature • Hyperlysinemia Extra Mile • Simple ectopia lentis: Superior displacement of lens • Sunset syndrome: Inferior subluxation of IOL • Sunrise syndrome: Superior subluxation of IOL • Lost lens syndrome: Complete dislocation of IOL into vitreous cavity.

questions.text: Which of them is not a characteristic of open angle glaucoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Disc edema • Primary open-angle glaucoma also known as chronic simple glaucoma of adult onset. • Characterized by: • Slowly progressive raised intraocular pressure (>21 mm Hg at least on few occasions) • Open normal appearing anterior chamber angle • Characteristic optic disc cupping • Specific visual field defects.

questions.text: Beta blocker should be avoided in all given conditions; EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Glaucoma • Topical beta-blockers have long been the mainstay of open-angle glaucoma therapy. • When an individual is already using systemic beta-blockers, the response to topical beta-blockers is often not optimal • Preferred beta blocker in OAG: Timolol • Preferred beta blocker in patients with history of bronchial asthma: Betaxolol

questions.text: Phacomorphic glaucoma occurs due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Intumescent cataract • Phacomorphic glaucoma is most common lens induced glaucoma (secondary ACG). • It is caused due to intumescent/swollen, cataractous lens. • The swollen lens pushes the iris forward resulting in secondary ACG.

questions.text: Which of the following is the carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in glaucoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dorzolamide • Timolol: Beta blocker. Decreases aqueous secretion from ciliary epithelium. DOC for POAG in India. • Overall, DOC for OAG is latanoprost. • Mannitol: A hyperosmotic agent. Reduces vitreous volume and deepens anterior chamber. • Prostaglandin analogue: Latanoprost, Bimatoprost: Increases uveoscleral aqueous outflow. Considered as DOC for OAG. Acetazolamide, • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor: dorzolamide, brinzolamide. Acts by decreasing aqueous secretion.

questions.text: In myopia image is formed at:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterior to retina • Near-sightedness, also known as short-sightedness and myopia, is an eye disorder where light focuses in front of, instead of on, the retina.• This causes distant objects to be blurry while close objects appear normal. • Other symptoms may include headaches and eye strain. Severe nearsightedness is associated with an increased risk of retinal detachment, cataracts, and glaucoma.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complaints of repeatedly changes glasses, this may possibly be due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Keratoconus • In keratoconus the patient presents with progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism due to change in the curvature of the cornea. The vision becomes more blurred and distorted which can be associated with colored halos glare and photo phobia. • The patient presents with frequent change of glasses because of this progressive change. • Glaucoma also presents with frequent change of glasses but it is mostly a frequent change of presbyopic glasses in an elderly person.

questions.text: A man with convergent squint in one eye, vision is 6l and another eye no squint with vision 6/60. Next step management is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Squint surgery • Squint surgery usually involves tightening or moving one or more of the outside ocular muscles which move the eye to change the eye position. • These muscles are attached quite close to the front of the eye under the conjunctiva, the clear surface layer. The eve is never taken out of the socket during surgery. Stitches are used to attach the muscles in their new positions. • Muscle recession surgery means weakening the muscle and muscle resection surgery means strengthening the muscle. • The recession surgery is done in restrictive squint whereas the resection surgery is done in the paralytic squint.

questions.text: In Vision 2020, which disease has been added recently for India:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Glaucoma Articles • Vision 2020 "Right to Sight" was launched as a collaborative movement by World Health Organization (WHO) and International Agency for Prevention of Blindness (IAPB [representing governments and nongovernmental organizations] in Geneva on February 18, 1999. • Vision 2020 has identified certain conditions which require immediate attention in India. These are: • Cataract • Childhood blindness • Refractive errors and low vision • Corneal blindness • Diabetic retinopathy and • Glaucoma (recently added)

questions.text: A newborn is hypermetropic by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) +2.5 D • A newborn is hypermetropic by +2 to +3 D (average: 2.5 D) EYE AT BIRTH • AP diameter: 16.5 mm (adult size 24 mm by 7-8 years) • Corneal diameter: 10 mm (adult size 11.7 mm 2 years) • NB hypermetropic by 2-3 D • Fixation starts at 1 month. Completed by 6 months • Retina: Fully developed except macular area • Macula fully developed by 4-6 months • Fusional reflex and accommodation well developed by 4-6 months • 3D depth perception/stereopsis - 6 years • Lacrimal gland: Underdeveloped (tears not secreted) • Anterior chamber: Shallow and angle is narrow • Orbit is more divergent (50°) as compared to adults

questions.text: Obstacle in manifest squint-concomitant type is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above 6th ed. pg. 347-348 • Manifest squint is of two types: Concomitant squint and Inconcomitant squint. • Concomitant squint: • Due abnormality/obstacle in binocular vision development, namely sensory, motor and central

questions.text: Crowding phenomenon is seen in;
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amblyopia The visual deficit associated with amblyopia has certain unique characteristics, including the crowding phenomenon, the neutral density filter effect, and eccentric fixation. The crowding phenomenon relates to the fact that patients with amblyopia have better visual acuity reading single optotype than reading multiple optotypes in a row (linear optotypes). Often, patients with amblyopia will perform 1 or 2 Snellen lines better when presented with single optotypes versus linear optotypes. This crowding Phenomenon may have something to do with the relatively large receptive field associated with amblyopia. Crowding bars are often used around a single optotype to provide a more sensitive test for amblyopia.

questions.text: What is the best treatment of Amblyopia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Occlusion • Amblyopia refers to a reversible decrease of vision, and is also referred as to lazy eye. • Treatment of amblyopia should be started as early as possible, younger the child better is the prognosis. • Occlusion therapy is the mainstay of therapy in which healthy eye is occluded to force the fixation of amblyopic eye. • Before occlusion any opacity in the media should be removed and any refractive error should be corrected. • However atropine penalization can also be done in better eye. Atropine causes cycloplegia and hence blurring of vision, which also forces the fixation of amblyopic eye.

questions.text: If the eye has a perforating injury. Which are a is most susceptible for developing sympathetic ophthalmitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ciliary body • Sympathetic ophthalmitis is Bilateral granulomatous panuveitis which follows a penetrating ocular trauma. • In penetrating injury ciliary body injury is more common. Ciliary region the so-called dangerous zone is more prone to injury due to penetrating trauma. • Wounds with incarceration of the iris, ciliary body or lens capsule are more vulnerable. • Injured eye is exciting eye and the fellow eye also develops uveitis is called sympathizing eye. Pathology • Allergic theory is the most accepted theory which postulates that the uveal pigment acts as an allergen and excites plastic uveitis in the sound eye (normal eye).

questions.text: Evisceration is removal of which layer of eye ball?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Middle and inner • Eyeball has 3 layers: Sclera, Choroid and Retina • Evisceration is removal of eyeball leaving behind the sclera (the outer layer). • Frill evisceration is preferred over simple evisceration, where about 3 mm frill of the sclera is left round the optic nerve. Indications: • Panophthalmitis • Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage • Bleeding anterior staphyloma Extra Mile • Enucleation is excision of eyeball. • In adults performed under local anaesthetics and in children under general anaesthetics • Indications: • Retinoblastoma and Malignant melanoma • Painful blind eye • MC indication for enucleation: Eye donation from cadaver

questions.text: First sign of sympathetic Ophthalmitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Retrolental flare • Sympathetic ophthalmitis is bilateral granulomatous panuveitis. It occurs as a result of penetrating ocular trauma (exciting eye), which can involve the contralateral eve (sympathizing eye) due to uveal pigment allergen released from the injured eye. • Symptom: • Photophobia and transient indistinctness of near object • Signs: • First sign: Presence of retrolental flare and cells or the presence of few keratic precipitates at the back of cornea. • Mild ciliary congestion • Edematous disc • Treatment: • Best prophylactic therapy: Early excision of injured eye • If there is hope of saving injured eye: Repair the wound + topical and systemic steroid and antibiotics along with atropine • If no relief or photophobia, KP and lacrimation persist after 2 weeks of treatment -> excise the injured eye immediately

choices.text: Only I and II are correct
II, IlI and IV are correct
I, II, and III are correct

questions.text: A patient with a history of fall on symmetrical surface, presents with enophthalmos, diplopia on upward gaze and loss of sensitivity over cheek. True statement about this is: I. Strongly suspecting orbital floor fracture II. It is a blow-out fracture III. Zygomatic bone is most likely injured IV. Frontal bone fracture
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Only I and I are correct • Blow out fracture is comminuted fracture of orbital floor and medial wall. • It result from trauma to orbit by relatively large, round object like tennis ball, cricket ball, human fist or a part of automobile. • Orbit is made of 7 bones: • Orbital floor: Maxillary and palatine bone • Medial wall: Ethmoid and Lacrimal bone • Lateral wall: Zygomatic and Greater wing of sphenoid • Roof: Frontal bone • Clinical picture: • Periorbital edema • Paraesthesia and anaesthesia: Over cheek, side of nose, lower eye-lid, upper lip due to involvement of infraorbital nerve. • Enophthalmos: Due to protrusion of orbital fat into maxillary sinus (X-ray: Tear drop sign). • Diplopia: Due to extraocular nerve entrapment • Treatment: • Avoid nose blowing • Systemic antibiotics (as prophylaxis) and analgesics • Cold compress (decreases swelling by vasoconstriction) • Surgical repair of plate (10-14 days after injury)

choices.text: Punch at the chin from below

questions.text: Blow out fracture can be due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tennis ball injury

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Herpes zoster • This is looking like herpes zoster infection. • Hutchinson's rule: It implies that ocular involvement is frequent if the side or tip of nose presents vesicles, this is due to cutaneous involvement of nasociliary nerve.

questions.text: Identify the image and disease associated with the given image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Retinoblastoma • The shown histopathological image is Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which is a characteristic finding of retinoblastoma. • Retinoblastoma (R) is a rare form of cancer that rapidly develops from the immature cells of a retina, the light-detecting tissue of the eye. • It is the most common primary malignant intraocular cancer in children, and it is almost exclusively found in young children. • Almost half of children with retinoblastoma have a hereditary genetic defect associated with retinoblastoma. • In other cases, it is caused by a congenital mutation in the chromosome 13 gene 13q14 (retinoblastoma protein).

questions.text: A patient with miosis, anhidrosis and mild drooping of eyelid as shown in the image is presented to the clinic. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Horner syndrome • Horner's syndrome, also known as oculosympathetic paresis, is a combination of symptoms that arises when. • The signs and symptoms occur on the same side (ipsilateral) as it is a lesion of the sympathetic trunk. • It is characterized by miosis (a constricted pupil), partial Causes of Miosis ptosis (a weak, droopy eyelid), apparent anhidrosis. (decreased sweating), with apparent enophthalmos (inset eyeball).

questions.text: Visual loss due to cerebral degeneration is related to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Posterior cerebral artery • The medial face of the visual cortex receives branches from the posterior cerebral artery (throughout its collaterals: calcarine artery, parieto-occipital artery and posterior temporal artery; • Its lateral surface receives cortical branches from the middle cerebral artery and its inferior surface is irrigated from collaterals of the posterior temporal and temporo-occipital arteries. • Some of the branches penetrate directly the visual cortex perpendicularly and others form at first, a superficial. pial network.

questions.text: A tumor in the anterior pituitary causing pressure over optic chiasma will present as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bitemporal hemianopia • Any optic chiasmal lesion like pituitary adenoma, will cause bitemporal hemianopia. • Detailed image and description of this is discussed in neuro-ophthalmology section of this book.

questions.text: In a patient of head injury, who presents with headache and increased intracranial pressure, the effect on pupil is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ipsilateral mydriasis Ocular signs in head injury can be seen due to concussion injury or base of skull bone fracture

questions.text: All of the following conditions cause miosis; EXCEPT:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Oculomotor paralysis

questions.text: Superior quadrantic hemianopia is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Temporal lobe lesion • Superior quadrantic hemianopia is also termed as “Pie in the sky". • It is produced when inferior fibres are involved in temporal lobe lesions. Inferior most fibres of optic radiation form the so called Meyer's loop. • Remember, inferior fibres of optic radiations contain fibres from ipsilateral lower temporal retina and contralateral lower nasal retina. • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia is "Pie on the floor? It is produced when superior fires are involved in parietal lobe lesions • Other choices like pituitary adenoma (MCC), craniopharyngioma and meningioma are the causes of chiasmal lesions, which causes bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: Which of the following lesions occurs at optic chiasma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bitemporal hemianopia

questions.text: In which of the following condition there is ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia and facial palsy of upper motor neuron?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Weber syndrome • Benedict's syndrome: Characterized by ipsilateral CN 3 palsy associated with tremors and jerky movements of the contralateral side due to involvement of the red nucleus. • Millard-Gubler syndrome: Consist of ipsilateral CN 6 palsy, contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral facial palsy. • Foville's syndrome: Contralateral hemiparesis with ipsilateral abducens and facial palsies. • Terson syndrome: Combination of bilateral intraocular hemorrhages and subarachnoid hemorrhage due to aneurysmal rupture.

questions.text: A patient presents with right sided field defects in both eyes, bur central vision emains unaffected. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problems and has a history of cataract surgery. OCT finding is shown below. What is the syndrome most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- B

questions.text: The cover-uncover test is powfermed to diagnose various eye conditions. Which of the following is NOT etected by this test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- D

questions.text: Which of the following is a side effect of PG analogue?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A 5 -year-old child presents with a refractive error of +1Dn the left eye <- 2D i the right eye. . Fundus examination reveals normal visual acuity and retinal idings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- C

questions.text: A patient sustainec blunt trauma to the eye 6 months ag and now presents with blurring of vision. What is the most likely conditions
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby is brought by the mother with complaints of the left upper eyelid moving up and down during breastfeeding or thumb sucking, which disappears when the baby is not being fed. What is the most likely diagnosig?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.text: A patient has a history of a flying foreign body injury to the eye. Ocular findings revealed iris pigmentation. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in the deposition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

The condenser lens needs to be kept close to the eye

questions.solution: Correct Answer :- D

questions.solution: Correct Answer :- D

questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.solution: Correct Answer :- A

questions.solution: Correct Answer :- C

questions.text: A corneal wisp test was performed, and the corneal reflex was elicited. Which of the following nerves is responsible for the afferent limb of this reflex?
questions.solution: Correct Answer :- B
